title: Jobs ‘just wanted to be important’
text:
Steve Wozniak: Apple co-founder Steve Jobs just wanted to be important, didn’t know technology by: What are these? Partners ... Steve Jobs and Steve Wozniak, left, who founded Apple in 1976. Picture: Supplied Source: AFP 
APPLE co-founder Steve Wozniak has said that the late Steve Jobs “didn’t know technology” and “just wanted to be important” when they started Apple. 
The 65-year-old made the comments while speaking to YouTuve channel Reach a Student. 
Wozniak says Jobs, who died in October 2011, played no role in the design of the Apple I and Apple II computers. Steve Wozniak interview 
Sarina Khemchandani, a 14-year-old entrepreneur who runs the YouTube channel, interviewed the Apple co-founder. 
“I’ve overheard you were able to overcome many hardware and software issues in the making of the early Apple computers. What role did Steve Jobs play during this time?” she asked. 
“Steve Jobs played no role at all in any of my designs of the Apple I and Apple II computer, and printer interfaces, and serial interfaces, and floppy disks and stuff that I made to enhance the computers,” Wozniak said. “He did not know technology. He wanted to be important, and the important people are always the business people. So that’s what he wanted to do.” Telling stories ... Apple co-founder Steve Wozniak says Steve Jobs “just wanted to be important”. Picture: AP Source: AP Icon ... Steve Jobs passed away October 5, 2011 after a long battle with pancreatic cancer. Picture: Getty Source: Getty Images 
Jobs and Wozniak met in 1971 when they were introduced by a mutual friend. They decided to 
set up a business after both attended the Homebrew Computer Club in San Francisco. 
The Apple I was hailed as the first ‘real’ home computer and was hand built by Wozniak in a garage in 1976. 
It went on sale for $US666.66 ($950), and 200 were made. 
After approaching a local computer store called The Byte Shop, Jobs and Wozniak built a further 50 Apple I computers and went onto to design a range of successors. 
Wokniak went on to say that Jobs knew nothing about how the Apple computer worked. 
“The Apple II computer was the only successful product Apple had for its first 10 years, and it was all done, for my own reasons for myself, before Steve Jobs even knew it existed,” he said. “So I had created it, and it was just waiting for a company. Steve Jobs was my good friend, the businessman.” Early beginnings ... Steve Jobs, chairman of Apple Computers, John Sculley, president and CEO, and Steve Wozniak, co-founder of Apple, unveil the new Apple IIc computer in San Francisco in 1984. Picture: AP Source: News Limited
